Leonisa joined HSPFI as a member in 2011. In the future, Leonisa hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy fish to sell

loans.name: Deysi Yolanda

texts.es:
La  joven Deysi tiene 27 años de edad, vive en el caserio Soni y se dedica a la venta de productos de consumo diario, Deysi es una mujer trabajadora y con muchas ganas de salir adelante, su negocio esta ubicado en su casa de habitacion, la joven Deysi se levanta a las 5 de la mañana todos los dias para atender a su  clientela, el credito lo utilizara para comprar mercaderia al por mayor y asi surtir su negocio, se aproxima la navidad y quiere comprar unos productos que no tiene en existencia y que sus clientes le estan pidiendo.
Deysi es madre de 2 hijos los cuales estan pequeños de edad.
      
Sus tiempos libres se lo dedica a sus hijos y tambien a la crianza de gallinas y cerdos.
texts.en:
Deysi is a young person, 27 years old. She lives in the village of Soni and she sells basic staples. 

Deysi is a hardworking woman and is eager to get ahead. Her business is located in her home. Deysi gets up at 5:00AM every morning in order to assist her clients. 

This loan is to buy merchandise at wholesale to supply her business. Christmas is on the way and she wants to buy some products that she does not have on-hand that her clients have been asking for.

Deysi is the mother of 2 young children. In her free time she takes care of her children and she raises chickens and pigs.

loans.use: to buy groceries, basic grains and dairy products

loans.name: Azamjon

texts.ru: Аъзамджон занимается скотоводством. Он целеустремленный и добросовестный семьянин. Он женат и имеет троих детей. Аъзамджон хочет улучшить свое жилищные условия и расширить свой бизнес для того чтобы содержать свою семью в хороших условиях семьи. Также он занимается выращиванием сельскохозяйственных культур. Отходы сельхозкультур идут на корм скота. Он хотел бы получить займы в размере 3000 Сомони для покупки одного  крупного рогатого скота и 2 голов мелко рогатого скота.
texts.en: Azamjon raises livestock.  He is a goal oriented and honest family man.  He is married and has three children.  Azamjon would like to improve his living conditions and to grow his business in order to support his family in good conditions.  He also grows agricultural crops.  The waste from crops is used to feed the livestock.  He would like to take out a loan of 3,000 Somoni in order to purchase one head of cattle and 2 heads of small livestock.

loans.use: to buy livestock

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to increase his stocks of wheat flour, baking flour, sugar, and cooking oil.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to pay for fruits like orange, guava, avocado and soursop to produce fruit juice

loans.name: Dorce

texts.en:
Dorce is a 42-year-old widow who is living with three children, they are: Jack, 19 and graduated from Senior High School; Fredy, 12 and studying at the 2nd grade of Junior High School; Kartika, 10, studying at the 4th grade of Elementary School.

Since the death of her husband, Dorce automatically took on the responsible to support her children. She struggles in covering her children's educational fees. Prior to running a kiosk business, Dorce used to sell vegetables at her house. She started her kiosk business in 2009. 

Dorce plans to improve her business by selling vegetables at her kiosk, as the community members around her residence usually buy vegetables from the roundsman. Currently Dorce is seeking additional capital to improve her business. Her neighbor suggested to her to apply for a loan from TLM. 

Dorce is requesting a loan of IDR 3,000,000 from TLM to add a greater variety of products, e.g., biscuits, soft drinks, snacks and fresh vegetables as well at her kiosk. Dorce really hopes that she can receive the loan soon.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of products, e.g., biscuits, soft drinks, snacks and fresh vegetables.

loans.name: La Gloire 2 Group

texts.fr: Le groupe LA GLOIRE 2 est composé de trois personnes qui sont des amies. La représentante du groupe, du nom de Sonnon Edwige (Celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) âgée de 34 ans a arrêté l’école au cours secondaire. Sonnon Edwige ne vit plus avec son mari et mère d'un enfant, scolarisé et à sa charge. Sonnon Edwige vit ensemble avec ses enfants. Les charges familiales sont supportées par la bénéficiaire. Pour ce faire, Sonnon Edwige vend des bazins riches depuis une dizaine d’année. Sonnon Edwige s’approvisionne au Mali. Dans le but de diversifier son activité, Sonnon Edwige ensemble avec les membres du groupe LA GLOIRE 2 sollicite pour la deuxième fois un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Les crédits antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.

loans.use: Acheter des bazins riches.

loans.name: Nilda

texts.es:
La socia Nilda pertenece al banco comunal "Anna Jarvis III”, ella continua dedicándose a su negocio de venta de ropa, con esta actividad sale adelante y aporta económicamente en su hogar. Ella desea ampliar su mercadería por fiestas de fin de año, ya que es la temporada del año donde la demanda de ropa se incrementa.
La socia solicito el crédito para comprar pantalones jeans, casacas y chompas.
La socia está contenta y agradecida con los inversionistas de KIVA por seguir confiando en ella.

loans.use: para comprar pantalones jeans, casacas y chompas

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: A 31-year-old experienced trader, Mrs Mercy B. sell food items for people in her community. To meet the demand of her customers, she needs a loan of $350.

loans.use: To buy more food items for sale

loans.name: Ovidio

texts.en:
Ovidio has been farming rice on his land for 20 years. He and his family of four children all still live on the farm. He works the fields with his sons, one who is pictured, and they all share in the profits. He also grows watermelons, maize and green peppers on his farm. He will be very happy to receive a loan and hopes he can invest in fertilizers and pesticides to nurture his crops.

Communal Banking in Baba

This borrower is part of the newest and largest Communal Bank in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Centro Agricola de Baba Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in the county of Baba in rural Ecuador. Their association works cooperatively to cultivate rice and commercialize the product after it has grown. As an association, Centro Agricola helps the farmers by providing access to machinery and training services. The farmers from Centro Agricola have received special instruction on financial responsibility and accounting from Codemicro, an organization that specializes in training programs geared towards the rural sector.

The members of Centro Agricola de Baba will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others' guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Centro Agricola de Baba Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Santa Lucia compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program.

Economy of Baba

The people of Baba have been organized since the days of Gran Colombia when Ecuador was yet to be a country. The area has always been popular because of the extremely productive lands that gave way to cultivation of cacao for decades. Now Baba is a county in the province of Los Rios in the coastal region of Ecuador. For most of the latter part of the 20th Century it was a cacao and banana-producing sector. Most of the surrounding areas of Baba in Los Rios are owned by large multinational companies such as Dole, but Baba is a sector characterized by small and informal farms.

Rice production has now turned into the main economic activity of the sector as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Cacao is still very popular in the area, but because of the long cultivation cycle people prefer to invest in rice. The lands in Baba are very fertile though, and most farmers in the sector often grow other crops, such as plantains and soybeans as secondary sources of income. Many farmers also keep livestock as emergency sources of food and income, commonly resorting to selling a chicken or pig if they are in need of cash.

Rice Farming in Santa Lucia

Most of the people in the Baba area are small farmers. They produce about 80 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds, plowing and leveling the lands. This is the most difficult part for the farmers in Baba, who often lack the necessary machinery to properly plow the lands for rice production. After appropriately preparing the lands, the farmers fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water-intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production.

Access to Credit

One of the biggest struggles in the area has been the lack of credit due to the absence of any type of financial institution. Because people do not count on formal financial finance, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

Risks

The largest risk in the sector is due to absence of watering systems. Although Baba is in the province “Los Rios” (the rivers) there is severe problem with access to water. The lack of infrastructure in the sector does not allow the small farmers to benefit from the presence of the many rivers in the area. If the winter season is too dry, it is likely that the lands will not be sufficiently fertile for rice production in the summer. On the other hand, if there is too much rain, there are not any drainage systems to prevent flooding and the crops are often ruined. Generally speaking though, Baba is a very productive sector where the lands yield all types of crops including rice, cacao, corn, watermelons, plantains, and soybeans.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will mostly be used to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. Many clients will use the capital towards renting machinery and equipment necessary to effectively work and prepare the fields. Clients also typically use a part of the loan to buy livestock in order to raise and have as reserves. The loan repayment schedule is different from the typical micro-entrepreneur because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures. Mifex asks our rural clients only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.use: Ovidio would like to invest in fertilizers and pesticides for his rice farm where he also grows watermelons, maize and green peppers

loans.name: Maria Isabel

texts.en:
My name is Maria C. and I sell farming products. I have had my business for four years. My business is doing good. However, right now I need to purchase medicines and poisons since I run out of inventory. My husband helps me attend to my business and with the earnings I make I'll be able to feed my family and cover my home's expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Yael Schwartzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Mi nombre es Maria C. me dedico a la venta de productos agropecuarios, tengo mi negocio hace 4 años, en el cual me va bien, pero en estos momentos necesito comprar varias medicinas y venenos ya que me quede sin inventario, tengo la yuda de mi esposo para atender mi negocio, y con las ganancias que obtenga poder alimentar mi familia y cubrir con los gastos de mi hogar.

loans.use: Purchase medicines, concetrate, flea and bug poison, chains and collars

loans.name: Lupe

texts.es:
Business Description

Lupe has had her business for 25 years, and she works with Chileans who brought this business to the country. She takes photos which are developed using oil paints. They take photos of the client and someone else develops the picture. They have been fortunate to have lots of clients. She works everyday from 9am – 5pm. Her husband travels to other provinces to attract more clients during the week. She is also starting to sell chicken by the pound from her house.

Loan use

She will use the loan to buy what her clients have asked for. This demand has grown thanks to the good customer service that she offers. She will also invest in chickens to sell from her home.

Personal Information

Lupe is 45 years old, married and has 4 kids; two of them work and two are single. They help with the household costs. Her husband helps in the business and studies; next year he will graduate as an agronomic engineer. He hopes to be able to earn more money for the family in this profession. Their house is made of cement. They hope that with the investment they will improve their family’s life.

Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

Descripción del Negocio

Lupe tiene una experiencia de 25 años con el negocio. Trabajo para unas personas chilenas que trajeron esta actividad al país. Realizando ampliaciones de fotos con pinturas de óleo. Ellos captan al cliente y otra persona se encarga de realizar la ampliación. Ha logrado tener una cartera buena de clientes. Trabaja todos los días de la semana en horario de 9 a.m. hasta las 5 p.m. Su esposo viaja en la semana ha otras provincias en busca de captar más clientes. Además en su domicilio esta iniciando con la venta de pollo por libra.

Uso del Préstamo

El crédito lo invertirá en realizar los pedidos que tiene pendientes. Su demanda ha crecido gracias al servicio que ella brinda a sus clientes. Otra parte lo invertirá en compra de pollos para su negocio en domicilio.

Información Personal

Lupe es casada. Tiene 45 años y 4 hijos. De los cuales dos ya trabajan y son solteros. Le ayudan en los gastos del hogar. Su esposo ha mas de ayudar en el negocio estudia. Esta próximo ha graduarse de ingeniero agrónomo. Espera poder ejercer la profesión y de esta manera generar otro ingreso al hogar. Su casa es de cemento. Esperando con la inversión realizada mejorar su vida familiar.

loans.use: To buy materials to meet her clients' demands/Comprar materiales para elaborar los pedidos pendientes

loans.name: Paridjahan

texts.en: Paridjahan (her husband is pictured) is 37 years old and a mother of three. Her husband started a transportation business five years ago. He transports goods to market with his car. The couple now needs a loan of $950 to purchase spare parts.

loans.use: To buy spare machine parts

loans.name: Domingos Francisco

texts.pt:
Domingos Francisco F. is 54 years old and a native of Buzi, Sofala province. He lived with his parents until the age of six. After the death of his father in 1959, he stayed with his mother until attending the 9th grade.

In 1979, he entered the National Defense Ministry as a soldier and was later transferred to the Ministry of Security where he worked until retirement. He married his wife in 1987 and moved in with her in the city of Matola. He currently has two children.

In 1994, he worked in the accounting department of the Guestetner warehouse in the harbor of the city of Maputo. In 2000 he moved to Boane and took his first loan from a credit association known as Tchuma that offered individual loans.

He came to know Hluvuku-Adsema in 2006 through a neighbor and applied for his first loan to purchase construction materials. With this loan of 15,000 MT he plans to finish building his home. He later plans to build a protection wall for his future house.

Translated from Portuguese by Leo Duran, Kiva Volunteer.

Localizaçao : Bairro 5 Cliente: Domingos Francisco F. Actividade :Habitação Valor de empréstimo :15.000,00 MT (600.00 USS) Aplicação : compra de material de construção Domingos Francisco F. ,de 54 anos de idade ,natural de Buzi ,província de Sofala ,cresceu com os seus pais ate aos 6 anos .Apos a morte do seu pai em 1959 continuou a viver com a mãe ate frequentar a 9ª classe. Em 1979 entrou no ministério da defesa nacional como militar e depois foi transferido para o ministério de segurança onde trabalhou ate ter a reforma . Juntou-se com a esposa em 1987 e passou a viver com ela na cidade da Matola ,tem actualmente 2 filhos . Em 1994 trabalhou como fiel do armazém na Guestetner na baixa da cidade do Maputo ,t No ano de 2000 começou a viver em Boane e teve o seu 1º empréstimo com uma associação de credito TCHUMA que oferecia créditos individuais . Conheceu a Hluvuku-Adsema desde 2006 através do vizinho e dai aproximou-se e solicitou o seu empréstimo para compra de material de construção .Com este credito de 15.000, 00 MT pretende concluir a sua obra. Futuramente a prespectiva é de construir um muro para vedar a sua futura casa.

loans.use: To buy material to build his house

loans.name: San Jacinto 1 Group

texts.es:
Clara Luz is a 55-year-old mother of 9. Her husband sells herbs for a living, while she runs a mini market from her home. The other members also have a mini market, with the exception of Amalia, who sells lotion, perfume, and cosmetics.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

CLARA LUZ TIENE 55 AÑOS, TUVO 9 HIJOS, SU ESPOSO VENDE HIERBAS. ELLA TIENE INSTALADO EN SU CASA UNA TIENDA DE ABARROTES. LAS DEMAS INTEGRANTES TAMBIEN CUENTAN CON UNA TIENDA DE ABARROTES A EXCEPCION DE AMALIA QUE VENDE CREMAS, PERFUMES Y COSMETICOS.

loans.use: Purchase of goods needed to restock a mini market

loans.name: Eude

texts.en:
Eude V. is married to Elba Rojas and they have two sons and a daughter who is the youngest.  Eude began a small telephone business based out of his house.  Here clients may come and use one of his few telephones and pay him when they are done.  He was able to begin the business by selling a plot of his own land in 2000.  Today, his wife runs the telephone business while Eude pursues other forms of income as a traveling street vender selling pasta. 

The business is profitable for what they have but they wish to invest more into the telephone business and make renovations to the facilities.  The loan will be used to buy computers so that they can sell the services of both telephones and computers.  With the addition of the computers, Eude’s business will have a more competitive edge and also offer more convenience for his customers.  This will attract more clientele, therefore increasing profits.  In the future, Mr. and Mrs. V. hope their business continues to flourish and that they will have enough money to construct a house of their own.

The woman who appears in the picture is Eude´s wife Elba, who is the manager of the telephone business.

loans.use: To buy more computers for their telephone business.

loans.name: Thol

texts.en:
Mrs. Thol C. ,42, has been married since 1985 and has five children--two sons and three daughters. One of her daughters is married and lives outside the family house, one of her sons is working as a blacksmith with her husband, and the other three children are studying in the local school.

Mrs. C. is in the business of charging batteries for the past year. Meanwhile, her husband has been a blacksmith for eighteen years. It’s a skill he learned in the city of Phnom Penh. They hope that their businesses will continue to support the family and allow their younger children to continue in school.

She is requesting a loan in the amount $1000 for the fifth time, to purchase blacksmith materials for her husband’s business.

loans.use: To purchase blacksmith materials

loans.name: Inobat

texts.en: Inobat U. was born in 1962 in the Spitamen region. She is married and has 6 children. She has been an active client of MLF MicroInvest-Tajikistan since 2007. She is engaged in the family livestock business but also has her own business selling soup kits, jellied minced meat and cooked trotters (pigs' feet). She has been in this business for 8 years. Now Mrs. U. is applying for a loan of 1,600 STJ to further her business development.

loans.use: Business development

loans.name: Manuela Altagracia

texts.en:
Manuela Altagracia, a 23-year-old mother of two daughters, lives in the Batey of Palavé community of San Cristobal.  To make a living and take care of her children, Manuela Altagracia sells pants to women in her community.
The entrepreneur explains that she wants to buy a house in a few years, but in the meantime she’ll keep working hard to move her business forward and improve her family’s living conditions.
With her loan, Manuela Altagracia will buy new styles of pants to resell in her community.

loans.use: Purchase of pants to restock a small clothing store.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy cloth in bulk for tablecloths, bedspreads and other goods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of clothing wholesale

loans.name: Ulugbek

texts.en:
H. Ulugbek is 27 years old. He is married with two children. Ulugbek is a very diligent and hard-working man. He uses his car to provide taxi services inside the city of Istaravshan. For the last four years the current business had been the main income for the family. It allows Ulugbek to improve the living conditions of his large family. In addition to his wife and children, he is also supporting his parents.

As with any business, it requires some investments from time to time. Thus, the car now needs to be fixed. For this purpose Ulugbek requests 600 USD for the term of 6 months. Ulugbek has proved himself to be a reliable client and promises to repay the current loan promptly. He thanks everyone for supporting him.

loans.use: Minor fixes of the vehicle used to provide taxi services.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Lâm 35 tuổi, chồng chị làm nghề xây dựng công việc của anh rất ổn định cho thu nhập hàng tháng là 2.000.000đ, gia đình chị có vườn rộng nên chị đầu tư chồng các loại rau ngoài ra chị còn làm thêm nghề hàng xáo. Chị tham gia quỹ năm 2003 vốn vay ban đầu chị vay 1.000.000đ đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn và làm vườn. Trải qua các năm vay vốn đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn và làm vườn nên kinh tế gia đình chị ngày càng phát triển. Chị đã sửa công trình phụ và chuồng trại chăn nuôi, mua sắm được nhiều tiện nghi trong gia đình. Hàng ngày chị đi chợ hàng sáo thu nhập bình quân mỗi ngày 50.000đ. Vòng vốn này chị xin vay 12.000.000đ đầu tư mua lợn và bò.
Thu nhập bình quân. 5.000.000đ/ tháng
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi L., aged 35, joined TYM Fund in 2003. Her husband is a construction worker with a stable income of 2.000.000 VND per month. Mrs. L. makes use of the large garden behind her house to plant vegetables and fruits. In the first round of loan, Mrs. L. only borrowed 1.000.000 VND to invest in raising pigs and planting. After many rounds of loans, the family’s financial situation has been improved a lot. Mrs. L. was able to renovate the toilet facilities, the places for poultries and purchase necessary furniture. Mrs. L. makes about 50000 VND daily from going to the market. In the next round of loan, she would like to borrow 12.000.000 VND ($725) to buy pigs and cows. Her family’s monthly income is 5.000.000 VND.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khoa Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cattle

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes Q. is divorced and has 6 children. She has received schooling through junior high education. Agnes sells bed sheets, soap, rice and other goods at Kokoado in Elmina, which she has done since 2004. Agnes uses her income to feed the family and pay their utility bills. Agnes will use this loan to add to her capital to increase stock for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Agnes plans to reinvest for the further expansion of her business.

loans.use: To add to her capital to increase stock

loans.name: Nicolasa

texts.es: Nicolasa tiene 28 años, es soltera y vive con sus tres hijos; Luis de 10, Cintia de 8 y Angélica de 6.  Gracias a la venta de queso, actividad que aprendió a realizar hace diez años atrás, ha logrado sacar adelante a sus dos hijas y poder brindarles comida y educación.  Nicolasa vende los quesos en el mercado Tupac Amaru desde muy tempranas horas de la mañana, dado que por esas horas existe mayor demanda de este delicioso producto y extiende su venta hasta las 2 o 3 de la tarde, aproximadamente.  Lo que le gusta de su trabajo, es que ella decide a que horas o cuando vender el queso, lo cual le permite tener cierto grado de libertad, lo dificultoso es que a veces la venta no es muy buena, haciendo que no obtenga lo suficiente para su gasto diario.  Nicolaza quiere que sus dos hijas terminen sus estudios y que obtengan un grado profesional para que no tengan muchas dificultades en el futuro.  Con el dinero que solicita cubrirá algunos gastos de su hogar y comprará mayor cantidades de queso para mejorar su venta y mejorar su pequeño negocio, a Nicolaza le gustaría tener otro negocio, como una pequeña tienda de abarrotes o un puesto fijo en el mercado Tupac Amaru.
texts.en:
Nicolasa is 28 years old, single and lives with her three children, Luis, 10 years old, Cintia, 8 years old and Angélica, 6 years old. Thanks to her selling cheese, an activity that she started 10 years ago, she has managed to provide her children with food and education. Nicolasa sells her cheese in the Tupac Amaru market starting very early in the morning, since those are the hours with the greatest demand for the delicious cheese, and continues selling until approximately 2 or 3 o'clock in the afternoon. What she likes about her work is that she can decide her own hours, which allow her to have a certain level of freedom; the most difficult of her work is that sometimes the sales are very good and doesn't cover her daily expenses. Nicolasa wants her two daughters to finish their studies and become professionals so that won't have many difficulties in the future. With the money that she is requesting, she will cover some household expenses and buy a larger quantity of cheese to improve her sales and her small business. Nicolasa would like to have another business, such as a small grocery store or a fixed location in the Tupac Amaru market.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying a larger quantity of cheese, which she sells

loans.name: Yan

texts.en:
Mrs. Yan C., 65, and her husband, Mr. Sok Chhun, 67, who live in a small village along national road number two about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh, were married in 1968 and have eight children; five sons and three daughters. They all married and live outside the family house.

Mrs. Yan has been selling meals and coffee for six months. Before she started this business, she was a fish seller. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver. She is requesting a loan to expand her business of selling meals and coffee.

loans.use: To expand her business of selling meals and coffee

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
Nida R. has a community-based store in Lullutan Ilagan, Isabela. Their village is located beside the Cagayan River, the longest river in the Philippines. She is married and blessed with two children. Although her husband is locally employed, their present income is not sufficient to meet their needs.

The people in their community prefer to buy their basic needs in a the store instead of going to the market, because it is difficult to go to the urban areas. To meet the demands of her customers, she must purchase additional products. which will require additional capital of Php7,000. She believes that the increase in her products will bring her more profit, which will give her the chance to save more for her family's future.

Nida believes in the golden rule: “Do unto others what you would like them do unto you.” Thus, their family lives simply and maintains good relation with their neighbors.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Azimjon

texts.en:
Azimjon M. is 36 years old and he’s married with three children. His wife is a housekeeper who looks after their children. Azimjon is the only breadwinner in the family and he is really hard working. He has a cafe where he sells the traditional meals and other foodstuff. He has been in this business for 3 years. Azimjon tries to have fresh foodstuff and tasty meals in his café, to ensure his clients enjoy eating, have a rest, and buy any other items they need. His business is stable, and this allows him to generate a significant income to ensure a good lifestyle for his family.

Azimjon’s children are now growing and the expenses of raising them are increasing too. Thus, Azimjon wants to increase his business to earn more money to cover the expenses of his children. With this purpose in mind, he is requesting a loan to expand his café. He plans to pay back the loan on time and thanks everyone for their support. Be an important part of the growth of Azimjon’s business.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and for its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets such as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New Western culture and Central Asian traditions. But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History:
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To expand his business in order to earn more money.

loans.name: Habibulla

texts.en:
Habibulla is the son of P. M. and lives in district 9 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is single, but as the oldest in the family, he needs to provide all the necessities of his family and pay for all the expenses. 

Habibulla has a car parts shop. He is requesting an individual loan of 50000 Afghani for a term of 12 months to buy tools he needs for his business. He is confident that the loan will enable him to increase his business.

loans.use: To buy tools for his car parts shop

loans.name: Soeun

texts.en:
Soeun R. is 32 years old and lives with his wife in Kandal province. He catches fish and sells his catch in the market, where he earns approximately $6 USD every day. His wife grows vegetables on her farm and makes about $5 USD each day. This couple has three childR., all of whom are in school. 

To catch fish to sell, fishermen need to pay the fishery officer a fee to rent the area in which catch fish. Mr. Soeun R. would like a loan to rent the fishing area to catch fish. 

Mr. Soeun R. is pictured on his wife’s farm.

loans.use: To rent a fishing area.

loans.name: Mara Karina

texts.es:
Mara inició el negocio  para poderle dar un mejor nivel de vida a su hija, por eso decidío abrir su negocio  y gracias a Dios le va muy bien.
Comenzó el negocio en Diciembre del 2006 con ayuda de su mamá que ya tenia experiencia en la venta de ropa y la cual en su momento le financio para emprender este proyecto  y pudo llevar a cabo la instalación de su tienda de ropa

Al principio fue un poco difícil porque el acreditarse tarda un poquito, empezo trayendo ropa de temporada y novedades y fue asi como las chicas se fueron acercando y logro hacerse de cleintes.

Ella necesita un prestamo por MXN  $3,000 que pagara en 8 catorcenas para comprar ropa de la temporada de verano y tener variedad para ofrecrle a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Mara began her business in order to provide a better life for her daughter, because of this decision to open her business, things have been going very well for her. Her business began in 2006 with the help of her mother who already had experience selling clothes. She was also able to get financing that allowed her to start her business.

At the beginning, it was a little difficult to get accounts with clothing distributors, but little by little, she was able to get clothing for the seasons and the latest styles. Girls started coming to her store and she was able to make them her customers.

She needs a loan for $200 that she will repay in 8 bi-monthly payments. She will use the money to buy summer clothing and to have a greater variety of clothing to offer to her customers.

(Translated by Jian of San Roque High School)

Translated from Spanish by San Roque School, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothing

loans.name: Sakina Abdul Sattar Group

texts.en:
Sakina baji, 39, is married and has lived in Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan for the past 19 years. Her husband is A. S.. He works in a factory and receives a monthly wage. Sakina baji is the mother of six children: two sons and four daughters. Her elder son also works in a factory and receives a monthly wage. The other children attend a school located near the house. Sakina baji embroiders dresses on orders that she collects from the clothing shops. She makes a good income from her business. She does this work to improve the living standard of her family. She is applying for a loan to buy materials (beads, colored thread, and cloth) for her decorative embroidery business. 

She is the group leader of three other women from her locality. Zubaida baji, Azra baji, and Maroofa baji each want a loan to buy buffalos for their dairy businesses. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy embroidery supplies

loans.name: Oyun

texts.en:
Oyun O. is a widow and lives with her youngest son in the Narantuul district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Oyun has a small business making shoes. She makes warm winter shoes for women and men. While she sews shoes at home, her son sells completed shoes in a rented stall in the Narantuul market, the largest open market in Ulaanbaatar.

Oyun has been running her shoemaking business for the last thirteen years and with the profits she has bought a car for her son so he can earn extra income. In his free time, Oyun's son uses his car as a city taxi. Oyun's goal is to ensure that her son will have enough working capital to keep the shoemaking business going after she is too old to work. She requests a loan to purchase raw materials, such as leather and glue for her business.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for making shoes

loans.name: Rann

texts.en: Mrs. Rann L. is 40 years old and she lives in Rolus village in Takeo province. She is a duck breeder. Since her poultry business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more ducklings to breed. She hopes to increase income and improve her family's living conditions. Her husband, Mr. Ven Saroeun, is a farmer who owns a piece of land and cultivates rice.She and her husband are shown in the photo.

loans.use: Purchasing more ducklings for breeding

loans.name: Mavzuna

texts.ru: Дадобоева Мавзуна-41 лет. Вдова и мать 2-х детей. Имеет среднее образование. Занимается продажей женский одежд и материал на рынке Панжшанбе.Так как её муж умер, она растит 2-х детей в одиночку и конечно же ей очень трудно. Мавзуна закупает свой товар из Турции. Мавзуна хотела, бы расширить ассортимент своего товара, потому, что хороший ассортимент привлекает больше клиентов. Для этого она предпочла взять займ для расширения своего ассортимента.
texts.en:
Mavzuna D. is 41 years old, and a widow with two children. She graduated from high school, and sells women's clothing and fabric at the Panjshanbe market. Since the death of her husband, she has raised two children by herself, and that has certainly been difficult. Mavzuna imports her goods from Turkey, and would like to expand the variety of goods she carries, because a broad selection attracts more customers. To this end, she took out a loan to expand her inventory.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Clothing sales

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie A. is from the town of Tagoloan, Misamis Oriental. She is 39 years old. Elsie is married and has 10 adult children. To make a living, Elsie owns & operates a business selling specialty food products in the local community. Elsie has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Elsie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Elsie is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP. She will purchase the raw ingredients that are needed to make the homemade food products that she has for sale in her small food stall. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Elsie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support needs of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase food ingredients for her business.

loans.name: Hermilita

texts.en: Hermilita C. is from the village of Corales, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 54 years old, married, and has two adult children. Hermilita works in a family member's business raising crops, primarily planting and harvesting corn for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In 2006, Hermilita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,500 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Hermilita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be her fourth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Suraiya  Abdul Haq Group

texts.en:
Zuhran baji wants a loan to buy construction supplies to sell. Razia baji wants a loan to buy embroidering materials (colored thread, beads and patterns) for preparing embroidered dresses. Hajra baji wants a loan to buy lentils, cooking oil and spices for her food-selling business. Rubina baji wants a loan to buy washing powders and bleach for her laundry business. 

Suraiya baji is the group leader of the aforementioned ladies. She is a very hardworking and caring lady. She gets up early in the morning and performs her duties very effectively. Her husband's name is A. H. and he works as a fruit seller. He has been doing this work for more than three years. He is also a very hardworking person. He treks to different communities and sells his fruits by announcing in a loud voice. Suraiya baji appreciates his struggle and gives him more attention when he comes back home. She is applying for a loan to buy seasonal fruits to advance her husband’s fruit-selling business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible. 

Note: Suraiya baji is seated first on the right side in this photo.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruits to sell

loans.name: La Solución 6 Group

texts.en:
Lucila A. M. (far right) is a hardworking mother of three seeking to augment her clothing sales business with her first loan through Esperanza. Selling shoes and used clothing, Lucila goes door to door to find out what those in her neighborhood need and travels to the Dominican capital of Santo Domingo to fulfill the orders.

Lucila has sold clothing for as long as she can remember, and has thus far been able to support her three children, ages 14, 13 and 8. With this loan, she hopes to further expand her business and use the profits for the benefit of her family. Currently, Lucila is expanding her home, but the addition lacks a roof and floor. She is hoping that as her business grows, she can finish the additional rooms of her home to accommodate the five people currently living under her roof.

A local university is opening in her city of Samaná, and Lucila is also planning on using her earnings to attend clases there to study real estate sales. She would love to someday help people sell their farms and other agricultural land.

Thank you for your loan to this Kiva entrepreneur! Lucila and the other four women in her solidarity group are all dedicated to wisely steward their new loan and use the profits from their businesses to provide a better living situation for their families.

loans.use: new clothing and shoes to increase sales inventory

loans.name: Oem

texts.en:
Mrs. Oem K. lives in Tuol Trea village in Takeo province. She is 25 years old and the mother of three children, one of whom is attending the local school while the others are just three and one year old. Her husband and children are shown in the photo with her.

Mrs. Oem K. is a cake maker. In her business, she needs a loan to buy a machine to make more cakes to sell to earn more income. Her husband, Mr. Oeurn Samnang, is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which he cultivates rice.

loans.use: To buy machine to make more cakes to sell

loans.name: Zainabkhon

texts.en:
S. Zainabkhon, a 47-year-old woman, is married with two children. Zainabkhon has a tailoring shop. Her business is sewing national women's dresses. Her workmanship is very good and, having been in this business for over 30 years, she has a good eye for design. She is very organized and has a good head for business. Zainabkhon started out with only one sewing machine, and now she has expanded her tailoring shop and has more than 20 assistants. With her loan, Zainabkhon will buy additional sewing machines in order to expand her shop. Given her spirit, she will surely succeed!

More about Tajikistan and IMON International: Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its epic mountain passes and its rich history which includes its place as a key post along the Silk Road and events at the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has produced famous thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. A civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged an already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural productivity and the manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent viable business prospects. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase sewing machines

loans.name: Ndolo

texts.en:
Ndolo M. is 36 years old and married to Mary Ndolo. Together they have three children who all go to school. Ndolo has been running a posho mill business for the last three years in Naivasha town. (A posho mill is a hammer mill that grinds maize into corn flour, which is then cooked and served as "ugali", a staple in Kenya.)

He joined KADET through a friend who is already a client. This is Ndolo's third loan with KADET. He used his first loan to buy a posho mill, and with his second loan he serviced the machine.

He now intends use this third loan to increase his stock by buying more maize, as this will enable him to increase his income and serve his loyal clientele better.   

Ndolo hopes his business grows and that he will be able to open a chain of posho mills outside Naivasha.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering their clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy maize stock

loans.name: Paul  Njenga

texts.en:
Paul is married to Jane and they have three children: Rachel, Irene and Callen.

Paul has been in the butchery business for six years. His other source of income is rental rooms. He was introduced to KADET through group members. Paul's business area is densely populated and his customers are residential clients. Paul will use his loan to open a new butchery within the market and to renovate his existing butchery shop.

With the extra profits, Paul intends to  pay school fees for his children. Paul's hopes are to expand the business and to become a wholesaler meat supplier as he believes he is focused, determined and hardworking.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Shs 60,000 will be used to open a new butchery within the market, shs 20,000 will be used to renovate his existing butchery shop.

loans.name: Aya

texts.en:
Aya J. is currently in the business of selling rice, beans and pulses. She is requesting a loan to purchase dried fish to sell.  Aya is 28 years old and is married. Her husband is a peasant. She has 4 children and 3 of them attend school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to help meet her family's food expenses.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase dried fish to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Rai Korb Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Rai K. has been selected village bank president by the 11 members of Village Bank Loan. All the members live in Krang Ta C. village in Takeo province and they all will use the loan for different purposes.

Mrs. Rai K. is 33 years old and the mother of four children who attend the local school. She is a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. S. Sarath, is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice.

Aside from this plantation, he is a construction worker. In this work, he has a problem because his work place is far from their house.

Thus, Mrs. Rai K. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to buy a motorbike for her husband to drive to work.

loans.use: To add to her savings to buy a motorbike for her husband to drive to work.

loans.name: Davaahuu

texts.en:
Davaahuu N. is 44 years old and the mother of two girls and two boys. She currently lives with her husband and four children in Hovd province, one of Mongolia's western provinces. Her two oldest children are 22 and 21 years old, and they currently pursue their small businesses. The 18-year-old daughter is a university student in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, and the youngest child is a 14-year-old daughter who is a secondary school student.

Davaahuu sells various animal skins and hides at the local black market. She purchases sheep, goat, and cattle skins and hides from herder families in the countryside and sell them at the market at a premium. She has been in the business since 1998. Last year, her business was affected by the price drop in the commodities market due to the economic crisis in Mongolia. She says that the business is starting to pick up and the demand for commodities is slowing recovering. Thus, she requests a loan to purchase more animal skins for her business.

About XacBank

XacBank was founded in 2001 and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here

loans.use: To purchase more animal skin

loans.name: Life Time Group

texts.en:
Patience V. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Life Time. She is 32 years old and married with two children aged 4 and 9 years old. Neither of them are schooling due to poverty. She is a high school graduate but could not continue to university due to lack of financial support.

Patience and her family live and work in the Barrolle community, Gbarnga City, the capital of Bong County, Liberia.

Her business is the sale of general goods. She buys general goods wholesale and sells retail to residents of her community in Gbarnga the capital of Bong County, Liberia. Patience has been running this business for two years and hopes to graduate from this small business to a better one.

The high price of goods and cost of transportation from wholesalers to her business site are really a difficulty for Patience’s business.

She needs this loan to purchase more goods to improve her business. Patience dreams of giving her family the best support.

loans.use: To purchase more goods to improve business.

loans.name: Silvio Jose

texts.es: Silvio José tiene 34 años de edad él se dedica a la venta y elaboración de comida. Su negocio inicia por la necesidad de obtener una fuente de ingresos económicos para poder mantener mi hogar y a mis hermanos menores anteriormente su mama era quien se hacía cargo del negocio pero debido a su edad no pudo continuar con él y fue Silvio quien decidió empezar de nuevo al inicio no tenía mucho afluencia de clientes pero con el paso del tiempo fue adquiriendo experiencia y mejorando sus platillos fue así que Silvio adquirió la fama necesaria. Ahora solicita financiamiento para comprar arroz, frijoles, huevos, plátanos, queso, repollo y carne.
texts.en:
Silvio José is 34 years old and dedicated to the production and sale of food. His business began due to the necessity of obtaining financial profit in order to maintain his home and provide for his younger brothers. His motherly previously led the business but due to her age she is no longer able to continue and Silvio decided to take it over. At the beginning he did not have many clients but as he acquired more experience and improved the courses of food offerred, with time he was able to acquire the necessary reputation. He is currently asking for a loan in order to purchase rice, beans, eggs, bananas, cheese, cabbage and meat.

Translated from Spanish by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase rice, beans, eggs, bananas, cheese, cabbage and meat

loans.name: Hermelinda

texts.es:
La señora Hermelinda es socia del Banco Comunal “La Juleñita” desde hace 3 años, vive en el distrito de Juli, provincia de Chucuito, departamento de Puno. Tiene 33 años de edad, es conviviente y tiene 02 hijos. Ella estudió secundaria incompleta, se dedica a la compra y venta de jabones, detergentes y otros.

Hermelinda nos cuenta que con el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos, que fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, pudo incrementar su capital y así comprar detergente, jabón, jaboncillo.

Ella requiere un nuevo crédito  de S/. 1,500.00 nuevos soles, con el cual podrá comprar jabon, detergente, cuchillos, champú, etc.

Su sueño para el futuro es tener su tienda de chifles y que sus hijos sean profesionales.

Lo que mas le gusta de su Banco Comunal son los ahorros.
texts.en:
Hermelinda, 33, has been a member of the “La Juleñita” communal bank for 3 years. She lives in Juli district, Chucuito province, Puno department. She lives with her life partner and has 2 children. She did not complete secondary school and she sells soaps, detergents and other products. Hermelinda tells us that with her first, 300 sol, loan from the Manuela Ramos Movement she was able to increase her capital and buy detergent and soap. She needs a new, 1500 new sol, loan to buy soap, detergent, knives, shampoo, etc. Her dream for the future is to have a fried plantains store and that her children become professionals. What she likes best about her communal bank is the savings.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy soap, detergent, knives, shampoo.

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina B., 67, is making sure that in spite of her old age, she can be self-sustaining to the point that she can help others as well. She has been managing her own variety store for 20 years.

Marina has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than eight years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow 23 times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to buy stock for her store. Her business lets her earn a net profit of 2,900 Philippine pesos per month.  

Now, with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 13,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying assorted beverages, snacks and toiletries for her store.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can continue to help her loved ones. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Buying assorted beverages, snacks and toiletries for her store

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en: Eunice loves sarongs and that is why she sells sarongs to make a living in Sapele, Delta state. She loves this business because she has the opportunity to interact with her customers. She hopes for a loan amount of NGN 60,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. She has children and she is happy that they are excelling in school. She is a friendly woman and she uses her friendly skills to attract more customers to her business. She says thanks to all KIVA lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more traditional African cloth

loans.name: Beinvinida's Group

texts.en:
Beinvinida E. is from the village of Upper Bayao, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She is the leader of a three-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.
Beinvinida is 75 years old, married, and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling fish in the local community. Beinvinida has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2010, Beinvinida joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About GDMPC
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Kaseso Group

texts.en:
Pilly Y., age 36, is married with two children ages 12 and 4 years. She has a general store business which started 6 years ago. She works from 6am to 10pm daily and she is able to make monthly profits of about $148.

This will be Pilly’s 1st loan from Tujijenge, Tanzania.  She hopes for a loan to start selling drinks like beers.

Pilly will share this loan with her loan Group Kosese which totals 15 members.  The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. 

In the picture, Pilly is in the orange dress. 1st from left second row

loans.use: To start selling different drinks like beers.

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua K. is a widow who has four children. She has not received any form of education.

Ekua sells maize and soap at Akotokyire. The photo was taken in her house where she had less stock of maize and soap to show since her stock was at the market.

Ekua uses her income in taking care of herself and her children. She will use the loan to purchase more bags of maize and soap for resale.

With the new profits from her extended business, Ekua plans to save to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of maize and soap to sell

loans.name: Ma. Arlyn

texts.en:
Maria Arlyn, photographed here with her 2-month-old child, hopes to have a big grocery store someday. She is 35 years old and married with six children. She lives in Trinidad, Bohol, with her family. Her store is currently located at her house. She and her husband work their best to be able to send all their children to school and hopefully have them finish college someday. 

She wants to grow her store so she could also earn more and sustain their needs. She applied for a loan of 3,000 Philippine pesos from CEVI, which she will use to buy sugar, oil and other merchandise she will sell at her store.

loans.use: Additional merchandise

loans.name: Roselfina

texts.es: Roselfina, de  29 años, vive con su esposo y sus 3 hijos en su casa que es propia.Desde hace 5 años trabaja en el  campo, además tiene vacas y una  granja de cuyes. Todas las mañanas sin excepción  cuida y alimenta sus animales con bastante dedicación, pues las ganancias de la comercialización y producción  de sus animales es bastante rentable .Al día Roselfina puede extraer de 10 a 12 litros de leche, además su granja de cuyes esta en aumento y los vende casi todos los días. Paralelamente se dedica al cuidado de sus tierras de cultivo, en esta temporada  esta sembrando pastizales de alfalfa que son indispensables para  la alimentación de sus animales.Es la octava vez que tiene un crédito con MFP, y promete que será muy responsable con sus pagos,  también agradece  a todas las personas que hicieron posible el  préstamo pues  le será  muy útil en el progreso de su negocio.Roselfina utilizará el dinero en la compra de más animales como cerdos y ovejas, para engordarlos y luego comercializarlos.
texts.en:
Roselfina, age 29, lives with her husband and 3 children in a house that they own. For the past 5 years, she has worked in agriculture. She also keeps cows and raises guinea pigs. Every morning, without exception, she feeds and cares for her animals with great dedication, since the income from their production and sale provides her with good profits. Each day, Roselfina's cows produce 10 to 12 liters of milk. Her guinea pig business is also expanding, with sales nearly every day. Parallel to this, she also cultivates her agricultural lands. During this season, she is planting fields of alfalfa, which is indispensable for her animals. This is her eighth loan with MFP, and she promises to be very responsible with her payments. She would like to thank all of the people who made the loan possible, since it will be very useful to her in developing her business. Roselfina will use the funds to buy more animals, such as pigs and sheep, to fatten and sell.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying more animals to raise and sell

loans.name: Carlos

texts.es: Carlos M. C., tiene la edad de 39 años, está en unión libre, y  tiene 4  hijos, tienen 1, 10, 16 y 17 años de edad. El crédito lo quiere para hacer reparaciones en su casa. Desea comprar materiales para poder mejorar las condiciones de su vivienda. También terminar algunos trabajos inconclusos en su casa. Es la primera vez que realiza un crédito con FUDECOSUR y está muy contento con las facilidades que se le brindaron. Don Carlos se dedica a la agricultura, tiene algunos años dedicado a la siembra del café. El espera en un futuro brindarle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida y una mayor estabilidad económica, y de poder seguir creciendo como persona y como productor.
texts.en:
Carlos M. C., 39, is in a common-law marriage and has 4 children: aged 1, 10, 16 and 17. He wants a loan to make repairs to his house. He wants to buy materials with which he can improve the conditions of his home. He also wants to finish some unfinished projects in his house. This is the first time that he has taken a loan with FUDECOSUR, and he is very pleased with the ease of payments they provide. Don Carlos works in agriculture; he has cultivated coffee for a number of years. He hopes in the future to provide his family with a better quality of life and better economic stability, and to be able to continue growing as a person and a farmer.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: home improvement

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Chan S., 54, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. She produces traditional cakes to sell for an income of US $3 per day. Her husband is a lock repairman and sews shoes, earning an income of about US $2.80 per day. S. is requesting a loan of US $600 to purchase more cake ingredients to produce more cakes for her customers. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her fifth loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients to produce more cakes

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Petty trading, like the sale of groceries, is widespread in Ghana because it is easy to start. It usually begins with tabletop selling and then grows to become a kiosk and eventually becomes a supermarket. Janet is one such entrepreneur. She has been selling groceries like washing powder, bottled water, canned foods, rice, cooking oil, toiletries, etc., for the past two years. Janet is 39 years old and married to a commercial driver. They have three children between the ages of 1 and 11 years. She is hoping that she will be able to expand her business and make more money to support the education of her children. She is excited to be taking out this loan, which she plans to invest in purchasing groceries in bulk to serve her customers. She anticipates increasing her profit and also expanding her market to include the sale of used clothes.

loans.use: To purchase groceries in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy maize, firewood and and a comal (typical Mexican griddle)

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
Leticia B. is from the village of Sto. Niño. She is 55 years old and married with four adult children. To make a living, Leticia has a retail store selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, talcum powder and toothpaste. Leticia has been engaged in her business for over 16 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Leticia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Leticia is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP which will also be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Leticia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the her business. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Demna

texts.en:
Demna Y. is from the town of Banga. She is 48 years old. Demna is married and has a 13 year old child. To make a living, Demna owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Demna has been engaged in her business for over 5 years. She works hard to improve her business and hopefully increase her harvest.

Demna joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Demna is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Demna from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income and improve their house. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Raul

texts.es:
El socio pertenece al banco comunal “NUEVA VICTORIA - CHINCHERO”;  Este banco está situado en el distrito de Chinchero, perteneciente a la provincia de Urubamba y departamento de Cusco; situado a 45 minutos de la ciudad.

El socio Raúl; tiene 28 años de edad; el socio es soltero y tiene 1 hijo, el socio se dedica a la fabricación de chompas en lana de alpaca, el socio tiene su pequeño taller en Cusco y confecciona chompas de alpaca, El socio trabaja en su taller produciendo chompas de alpaca al por mayor junto a sus operarios y luego los vende en diferentes ferias artesanales y también trabaja a pedido de otros. El socio solicita el préstamo para comprar lana de alpaca al por mayor teñidas y de colores naturales.

El socio  agradece el préstamo mediante este medio y del mismo modo se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo estipulado.
texts.en:
Raúl, 28, is single and has a son. He manufactures Alpaca wool sweaters in a small workshop he has in Cusco. He works in his workshop making Alpaca sweaters in quantity with his staff and then sells them in different crafts markets. He also works to fill third-party orders. He is asking for funds to buy Alpaca wool dyed in a variety of colors and in natural state. He is a member of the “NUEVA VICTORIA - CHINCHERO” (Chinchero New Victory) communal bank located in Chinchero district, Urubamba province, Cusco department. It’s located 45 minutes from the city. He avails himself of this forum to express his gratitude for the loan and to commit to repay it in a timely fashion.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy Alpaca wool, both dyed in various colors and natural, at wholesale.

loans.name: Speratha

texts.en:
Speratha is 38 years old. She is married and has five children between the ages of 3 and 13. All but her youngest child are enrolled in school. Her husband works with Urunana Company, an acting troupe that is hired to convey social messages through plays and other forms of entertainment.  

For the last five years, Speratha has had a shop where she sells things such as soap, alcohol, cooking oil and other food items. With the proceeds of this loan, she is going to make improvements to her shop.  She says that the success of her business is due to the good customer care that she provides.  With the profit from her business, she is going to save up for a piece of land.

loans.use: Improvements to the shop

loans.name: Haydee

texts.es:
Haydee de 41 años, es una mujer trabajadora, ella tiene un hijo,  Ángel de 16, de su primer compromiso, actualmente convive con Antonio, de 28 años, él tiene hijo, Anderson de 4 años, juntos se unieron y viven en su casa propia ubicada en la localidad de Chiras. 

Desde muy niña le enseñaron a trabajar la tierra, ayudaba a sus padres a mantener su terreno de cultivo, ya cuando consolidó su familia, se dedicó a sembrar y cultivar en su propio terreno de cultivo. Ahora cultiva en dos hectáreas de terreno, papa, arveja y habas; los que después comercializa en el mercado central de su localidad, pero en temporadas de mayor cosecha los mismos compradores van hacia sus mismos campos a comprar lo que ha cosechado. 

En todo este tiempo ella pudo adquirir dos toros, con los que puede arar la tierra, de esa manera evitará el gasto de contratar personal. Con el tiempo se comprará mas hectáreas de terreno de cultivo, para poder sembrar más cantidad de papa y poder obtener mejores ganancias. 

Es el primer crédito con MFP y promete ser puntual y cumplida con su banco comunal, ya que le apoyan y entre ellos comparten experiencias positivas. Con el crédito que obtendrá, podrá comprar abono para las 40 hectáreas de papa que está sembrando (2 son propias y 38 son alquilados).
texts.en:
Haydee, age 41, is a hard-working woman. She has one 16-year-old son, Angel, from a previous relationship, and she currently lives with 28-year-old Antonio, who also has a 4-year-old son, Anderson, from a previous relationship. They live together in their own house in Chiras.  

She has worked the land since she was a very young girl.  She helped her parents maintain their crops.  When her family consolidated six years ago, she planted and grew crops on her own land.  She now grows potatoes, peas, and beans on two hectares of land.  She sells them in the central market in her area.  However, during the season when there is a large harvest, the same buyers go to their own fields to buy what has been harvested.

During all of this time she was able to buy two bulls.  She is able to plow the land with them.  This way she avoids the expense of hiring workers.  In time she will buy more hectares of land to cultivate.  She will do this in order to plant greater quantities of potatoes and to be able to obtain better earnings.

This is her first loan with MFP, and she pledges to be punctual with her communal bank. They support her, and they share positive experiences.  She will use the loan to buy fertilizer for the 40 hectares of potatoes that she is planting (two are her own, the remaining 38 are rented).

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet K. lives in Naguru, a neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has 8 children, five of whom are in school.  

Annet has a business of selling charcoal. She has been in this business for 5 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Annet sells her products from home, by means of retail. Annet has requested for a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more sacks of charcoal. She also generates additional income through frying cassava and chips and plaiting hair.

The main business challenge(s) for Annet include seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start going directly to villages for charcoal. Annet lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Sayra

texts.en:
Sayra I. is 45 years old, single, and has three children.  Since her family has limited resources, Sayra is engaged in the bottle redemption business. She accepts empty bottles and resells them to large factories.  This activity, however, is not very stable and thus not always profitable.  In 2002, she decided to start her own business in cattle breeding.  She worked hard to develop her business and grew her monthly benefits to 4,000 KGS.  Now Sayra plans to use this loan of 60,000 KGS to purchase three bull calves which will allow her to earn income by means of livestock breeding.  In the future, she wants to give her children a good education.

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population.  Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan.  As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle.

loans.name: Nemat

texts.en: Nemat J.  is a 35 year old man who breeds cattle in the small village of Saatli city. He is married and has three children. Nemat has 3 years experience in this field. Currently he has three cows and his wife actively helps him. He sells milk and milk products to the local people but demand for milk products is higher than his cows can produce and this has pushed Nemat to purchase more cows to generate more milk. Nemat he has applied for a loan of 1000 AZN  to purchase more cattle. This will allow him to increase his profit and improve the living conditions of his family.

loans.use: To purchase three cows

loans.name: Jaih

texts.en: Jaih H. is 39 years old and lives with his wife and two children in the Bayan-Ulgii province of western Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Jaih operates a meat-trading business out of his own stall at the local market in his town. He began his business in 1999 with working capital of 200,000 Mongolin tugriks (MNT). After several years of operation, his working capital has grown to a level of 800,000 MNT today and he has managed to establish himself in the business community. Jaih says, "I want to expand my business and buy my own car in the future." He is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan in order to increase his working capital due to an increase in the price of livestock.

loans.use: To increase his working capital

loans.name: Aneit

texts.en:
